speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these episodes of stridor and wheezing, when did they first start and how often do they occur? Are they triggered by anything in particular, such as feeding or crying?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, it started a few months ago, and it happens almost every day. My mom says it gets worse when I'm crying or eating, and sometimes when she's burping me and my head is bent down, it sounds like I'm having trouble breathing."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's very helpful information, thank you for sharing that with me. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're feeding, does the stridor and wheezing occur with both breast milk and formula, or just one of them?

speaker: Patient
text: "My mom says it happens with both, but it seems worse when I'm drinking formula. She's tried different positions and everything, but sometimes I just start making that noisy breathing sound and she gets really worried, and then sometimes I throw up afterwards."

speaker: Doctor
text: That must be very concerning for your mom. Have you been experiencing any reflux or spitting up after feeding, aside from the times when you throw up after the stridor and wheezing episodes? REQUEST TEST: Upper_GI-Series.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal readings from the Upper GI Series are helpful to rule out some possibilities. Can you tell me more about your crying episodes, do they seem to trigger the stridor and wheezing immediately, or is there a delay between crying and the onset of symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Laryngoscopy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal laryngoscopy results are helpful in ruling out any anatomical issues with your larynx. Can you tell me more about your overall health, have you had any recent illnesses or infections that may be contributing to these episodes of stridor and wheezing? REQUEST TEST: Complete_Blood_Count.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: That's good to hear that your overall blood work came back normal. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're in different positions, for example, does the stridor and wheezing occur when you're lying on your back or stomach, or is it more pronounced when you're in a upright position? REQUEST TEST: Pulmonary_Function_Test.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal pulmonary function test results are helpful in ruling out any underlying lung issues. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're being burped and your head is bent down, does the stridor and wheezing occur immediately after your head is bent, or is there a slight delay? REQUEST TEST: Esophageal_pH_Monitoring.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal esophageal pH monitoring results help to rule out any issues with acid reflux. Can you tell me more about your physical development, are you meeting your milestones for growth and development, and have you had any previous surgeries or hospitalizations that may be relevant to your current condition? REQUEST TEST: Videofluoroscopic_Swallow_Study.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Findings of compression of the esophagus and trachea consistent with a vascular ring, as also suggested by other imaging studies such as Chest X-ray and Barium Swallow, which indicate evidence of tracheal compression and a vascular ring suggestive of a double aortic arch.

speaker: Doctor
text: The videofluoroscopic swallow study results are very telling, suggesting a vascular ring, possibly a double aortic arch, which could be compressing your esophagus and trachea, leading to the stridor and wheezing episodes. Can you tell me if you've had any previous imaging studies, such as a Chest X-ray or Barium Swallow, that may have hinted at this diagnosis? REQUEST TEST: Echocardiogram.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Confirmatory findings of a double aortic arch, consistent with the vascular ring suggested by the Videofluoroscopic Swallow Study, Chest X-ray, and Barium Swallow tests.

speaker: Doctor
text: With these confirmatory findings from the Echocardiogram, it seems we have a clear understanding of the underlying cause of your stridor and wheezing episodes. Can you tell me if you've experienced any other symptoms such as cyanosis, or blue discoloration of the skin, especially during these episodes? REQUEST TEST: Cardiac_Catheterization.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal cardiac catheterization results are helpful in further confirming the diagnosis. Can you tell me if you've noticed any differences in the severity of the stridor and wheezing episodes when you're calm versus when you're upset or crying, and do you have any family history of similar conditions or congenital heart defects? REQUEST TEST: MRI_of_the_aortic_arch.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Evidence of a double aortic arch, with compression of the trachea and esophagus, consistent with previous imaging studies, including Chest X-ray, Barium Swallow, Videofluoroscopic Swallow Study, and Echocardiogram.

speaker: Doctor
text: With all these confirmatory test results, I believe we have a clear picture of what's causing your symptoms. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difficulty breathing when you're playing or active, or if it's mostly just during feeding and crying episodes? REQUEST TEST: CT_Angiogram.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Confirmatory findings of a double aortic arch with tracheal compression and esophageal compression, consistent with previous imaging studies, including Chest X-ray, Barium Swallow, Videofluoroscopic Swallow Study, Echocardiogram, and MRI of the aortic arch.

speaker: Doctor
text: With all these test results consistently showing evidence of a double aortic arch with compression of the trachea and esophagus, I believe we've gathered enough information to make a diagnosis. Can you tell me one last time if there's anything else you or your mom have noticed that might be relevant to your condition, such as any changes in your appetite or overall energy levels?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my mom says I've been a bit more fussy than usual and don't seem to want to eat as much as I used to, especially after those episodes of noisy breathing. And sometimes I get really tired after feeding, like I just want to sleep all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's very helpful information, thank you for sharing that with me. It sounds like the stridor and wheezing episodes may be affecting your appetite and energy levels, which is consistent with a diagnosis of a double aortic arch. I think we've gathered enough information now, and I'm going to review all of your test results one last time before making a final diagnosis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Double Aortic Arch with Tracheal and Esophageal Compression.
